## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r}
# Plot the earthquake signal first
plot(EQ5, type="l", col="blue", lwd=2,
     ylab="Earthquake/ Explosion", xlab="Time")

# Add the explosion signal on top
lines(EXP6, col="red", lwd=2, lty=2)

# Add legend for clarity
legend("topright", legend=c("EQ", "EXP"),
       col=c("blue", "red"), lty=c(1,2), lwd=2)
```

```{r}
###1.3 autoregression
w = rnorm(150) # n=100+ 50 (extra to avoid startup problems)
x = filter(w, filter=c(0, -0.9), method="recursive")[-(1:50)]

# b)
x2=cos(2*pi*(1:100)/4) #t: from 1 to 100

# c)
x3=x2+rnorm(100,0.1)

v=filter(x, rep(1/4,4),sides=1)
v2=filter(x2,rep(1/4,4),sides=1)
v3=filter(x3,rep(1/4,4),sides=1)
```

```{r}
#par(mfrow=c(3,1))  
# d)
plot(x, main="autoregression", col=4, type="l") # col=4 means blue, type="l" means using line instead of dot
lines(v, col="red", lwd=2, lty=2) #lty=2 means dashed line

plot(x2, main="cosine", col=4, type="l")
lines(v2, col="red", lwd=2, lty=2)

plot(x3, main="cosine+noise", col=4, type="l")
lines(v3, col="red", lwd=2, lty=2)
```


Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
